title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 28 december [1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 28 December [1868]
text: 1868 (?)DecembeDecember 28well walterWalter deari couldentcouldn't let the week pass without writing a line or two i got your letter last week with the money order and the big book and wasentwasn't i glad it has so much to read about it will keep me quite a long time i doodo so like to have somethgsomething to read i am alone so much i have been down and got the order cashed and am going to have something good for the new year sNew Year's dinner i didentdidn't make any preperationspreparations for christmasChristmas) O waltWalt aintain't it sad about that young woman perhaps if she hadenthadn't got married she would have got over it the excitement probably aggravated the disease) it is sad indeed to read although strangers) i got the letter this morning all letters come first rate) i gave the carrier a dollar for his christmasChristmas he was much pleased such things go a great ways in having him punctual) i am as well as usual sleep pretty well i went down to gill sGill's and got a stove for the back room on georgeysGeorge's credit i have some company not very much i see a short account of the richmRichmond fire but i had no idea it was so horrible) with many thanks for money and books i remain yoyour affectionteaffectionate motherLove to mrsMrs. and mrMr. OconerO'Connor Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 28 December [1868]
